docs.lead_paragraph: Taking a lesson from the 1996 Presidential campaign, an array of candidates in this year's midterm elections has begun buying television advertising months earlier than usual, promising another election year likely to break spending records. Gone are the days when candidates husbanded their resources for pre-primary or post-Labor Day advertising blitzes. Representative Nancy L. Johnson, a Connecticut Republican who eked out a victory in 1996, spent close to $100,000 around New Year's on a television spot on her sponsorship of a health care bill.
docs.abstract: Array of candidates in 1998 mid-term Congressional elections are buying television advertising months earlier than usual, promising another election year that is likely to break spending records; strategists in both parties attribute trend to Pres Clinton, who in 1995 mounted most intensive television campaign ever by incumbent President in successful run for second term in 1996 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Frontline'' pays a house call on American medical care tonight. Under examination is whether the for-profit health maintenance organizations that are spreading throughout the nation are benign. The findings of ''The High Price of Health'' are not reassuring. H.M.O. members are discovering that some treatments, particularly expensive ones, are not covered by their plans. They are also discovering that hospital stays are getting shorter; patients are sent home before they feel ready to go.

headline.main: Quality of Care vs. Quest for Profits

docs.abstract: Walter Goodman reviews The High Price of Health, program in PBS's Frontline series examining complaints about health maintenance organizations in America; Waphoto (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When paramedics rescued him from a Brooklyn street last month, Arthur Bell Jr. was homeless and disoriented, a 71-year-old man who had lost part of his past: there were rich memories of Fonteyn and Balanchine and life as a dancer in New York and Paris long ago, but recent decades were a blur of impressions. Yesterday, though, after a chain of events that included a social worker's interest in his past as a pioneering black dancer, the publication of articles on Mr. Bell and a casual remark at an Easter service in Florida on Sunday, Mr. Bell was no longer a forgotten man in a nursing home.

headline.main: Black Dancer Is a Forgotten Man No Longer; Found Wandering the Streets, He'll Soon Be Reunited With a Big Family

docs.abstract: Arthur Bell Jr, 71, was homeless and disoriented when paramedics found him on Brooklyn street in March; he had rich memories of his life as dancer in New York City and Paris long ago, but he could not recall how he had come to be in Brooklyn; Bell, following chain of events that included social worker Maria Mackin's interest in his past as pioneering black dancer and publication of articles about him, is no longer forgotten man; Pat Coleman of Tampa, Fla, says Bell is her brother and that he has large family that has been searching for him for decades; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Back when they did not have much power, Congressional Republicans were united over the Federal budget because they believed in a world defined by a few simple evils: the deficit, spending, taxes, Democrats. But now that they control Congress and are facing surpluses instead of deficits, the party is more divided over budget policy than it has been in a generation. There is confusion about which, if any, tax cuts to favor. Some members have developed a strong taste for pork. Their divisions give President Clinton an upper hand not contemplated a year ago. Before the Easter recess, Republicans were waging what amounted to a civil war over who could spend more. Their focus was a highway bill loaded with so many embarrassingly porcine projects that Republicans now fear Mr. Clinton could actually veto it, tagging them as the party of profligacy. Things got so bad that the champion deficit hawk, John Kasich, chairman of the House Budget Committee, was said to be barely on speaking terms with Bud Shuster, champion of old-fashioned Interstate largesse. The disputes have forced Republican leaders to add a footnote to their longtime rule on shrinking the Government. It says: ''Except in my district.''
docs.abstract: Editorial says squabbling among Republicans in Congress about pork in budget and which tax cuts to pursue has given Pres Clinton upper hand; says he has insisted that any budget surplus be set aside to shore up Social Security system in long-term future; says Republicans know most Americans agree with him, and that they will be under enormous pressure to make some concessions to spend at least little more money on child care, schools and environment (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: SINGLE female baby boomers on Long Island have begun to confront retirement in the same way they would heed the rumblings of an approaching storm. They know some turbulence may be headed their way, but they are not quite sure how to prepare for it. ''Women start feeling the pressure of retirement planning at around 40,'' says Eve Schniebolk, a certified financial planner in Rockville Centre and past president of the Long Island chapter of the International Association for Financial Planners. ''The first thing a 40-year-old woman does is celebrate her birthday, the second is to give me a call.''
docs.abstract: Need for single female baby boomers on Long Island to pay more attention to financial planning for retirement discussed; National Center for Women and Retirement Research at Long Island University finds savings and investment patterns of women baby boomers are disturbingly inadequate, with over half of 1,000 women surveyed having no retirement savings; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN 1999, the Federal budget is projected to show a surplus for the first time since 1969. But if we do not want to run into another long string of deficits after that, we must recognize that the nature of Government programs has changed drastically, making it infinitely more difficult to maintain a balanced budget now than it was 30 years ago. Consider the budget in 1969, in the midst of the Vietnam War: Military spending and other traditional functions of Government -- areas that had no private alternatives, including the Treasury, Justice and State Departments -- absorbed 74 percent of the budget before interest on the Federal debt. Social programs represented only 26 percent.

headline.main: Keeping a Safety Net Under a Budget Surplus

docs.abstract: Charles J Zwich and Peter A Lewis article cites difficulty of keeping Federal budget in balance because of large percentage of budget spent on programs for individuals that substitute for or supplement private insurance and other private spending; warns relieving public sector of Social Security and health care costs by shifting them to private sector does not constitute saving (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ON a sunny morning recently, an elegantly dressed woman strolled down Fifth Avenue, turned onto East 72d Street and strode past million-dollar limestone maisonettes into the office of Dr. Adrienne Denese. The patient, a fashion publicity agent from the higher rungs of New York society, asked not to be named, but revealed that she visits Dr. Denese's clinic to receive her weekly dose of the 1990's version of youth elixir: human growth hormone. Dr. Denese, a trim blonde with skin that is smooth but oddly hard to the touch, is not your average physician. A series of injections of human growth hormone, or hGH, at her clinic, she maintains, gives patients glowing skin, increased muscle mass, elevated sex drive, a lighter mood, sharper mental acuity and the whiz-bang metabolism of an 18-year-old.
docs.abstract: Human growth hormone hGH, developed to treat children with dwarfism, is latest anti-aging fad among wealthy New Yorkers and Californians obsessed with avoiding droops, dwindles and sags of middle age; youth elixir is injected by doctors such as Bruce J Nadler and Adrienne Denese of Manhattan, despite Government warnings of potentially dangerous side effects; photo; other treatments are high-priced vitamins, hormones and enzymes prescribed by Dr Alan P Mintz at his Las Vegas clinic (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the 1950's and early 60's the men of rock and roll were mostly boys, and their names reflected that. It was Frankie Avalon and Frankie Lymon, not Frank. Danny led the Juniors. Bobby Lewis was ''Tossing and Turning.'' And Chubby, not Chub, Checker did ''The Twist.'' Consequently, record producers decided that the lead singer of the Cleftones would be known as Herbie Cox. Which was a problem, said Mr. Cox, who now goes by the name of Herb and lives in Freeport. ''You know what it was like being a Herbie in high school?'' he asked.

headline.main: Gathering Together, in the Spirit of Doo-Wop

docs.abstract: Over 20 acts from 50's and 60's will perform at rock and roll benefit concert, Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum; Herb Cox, lead singer of Cleftones, comments; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: I HAVE always made sure my kids got to the doctor regularly and my husband made an appointment for his physical, but I dreaded the hassle when it came to taking care of myself,''said Susan Datz, a teacher from Oceanside. ''Trying to find a doctor who remembered my name without checking my chart, someone who would talk to me when I felt like a person, while I still had my clothes on, and who understood that my complaints were real and not all induced by stress, was not an easy task,'' she continued. ''I knew many of my friends felt the same way. That's why I was so pleased to hear that Long Island Jewish Hospital was opening up a women's health care center. At last someone was listening to us.''
docs.abstract: Long Island, NY, hospitals are increasingly setting up special programs and other offerings to deal specifically with women's health problems; are spurred by growing demand from dissatisfied baby boomers and intense competition for customers; Long Island Jewish Medical Center and North Shore University Hospital have both opened state-of-the-art centers catering to women; photos (M)4
